#Text=CHAPTER VIII

#Text=In the throes of fever -- A ghastly discovery -- Pitiful relics -- A critical moment -- Yamba in danger -- A blood bath -- A luxury indeed -- Signs of civilisation -- The great storm -- Drifting , drifting -- Yamba 's mysterious glee -- A dreadful shock --
#Text="Welcome home ! " --
#Text=My official protectors -- Myself as a cannibal war chief -- Preparations for battle -- A weird apparition -- Generosity to the vanquished --
#Text=The old desire .

#Text=I had not been established in this camp many days , however , before I was struck down , for the first time , with a terrible attack of malarial fever , probably produced by the many hours I had spent wading in the swamps at Port Essington .
#Text=There were the usual symptoms -- quick flushings and fever heats , followed by violent fits of shivering , which no amount of natural warmth could mitigate .

#Text=My faithful Yamba was terribly distressed at my condition , and waited upon me with most tender devotion ; but in spite of all that could be done for me , I grew gradually weaker , until in the course of a few days I became wildly delirious .
#Text=The blacks , too , were very good to me , and doctored me , in their quaint native way , with certain leaves and powders .
#Text=All to no purpose , however ; and for several days I was even unable to recognise my Yamba .
#Text=Then the fever subsided somewhat , and I was left as weak and helpless as a little child .
#Text=It was some time before I quite recovered from the fever ; and I was frequently seized with distressing fits of shivering .
#Text=I also experienced an overwhelming desire for a drink of milk ; why , I am unable to say .
#Text=Therefore , when some of the blacks told me that wild buffalo were to be found in the neighbourhood -- beasts which had formerly belonged to settlers , but were now run wild --
#Text=I resolved , when sufficiently strong , to try and capture one of the cows for the sake of its milk .
#Text=Captain Davis ridiculed the idea , and assured me that it was only possible to slay one with a rifle ; but I determined to see what I could do .
#Text=Yamba , of course , accompanied me on my expedition , and her bushmanship was altogether quite indispensable .
#Text=We came upon buffalo tracks near a large water-hole , and here we each climbed a gum-tree and awaited the arrival of our prey .
#Text=We waited a long time , but were at length rewarded by seeing a big cow buffalo and her calf wandering leisurely in our direction .
#Text=My only weapons were a lasso made out of green kangaroo hide , fixed to the end of a long pole ; and my bow and arrows .

#Text=I slid down the tree a little way , and when the calf was near enough , I gently slipped the noose over its neck , and promptly made it a prisoner under the very nose of its astonished mother , who bellowed mournfully .

#Text=My success so elated Yamba that she , too , slid down from her hiding-place , and was making her way over to me and the calf , when suddenly an enormous bull , which we had not previously seen , rushed at her at full speed .
#Text=Yamba instantly realised her danger , and swarmed up a tree again like lightning , just as the great brute was upon her .
#Text=I called out to her to attract the attention of the old bull whilst I attended to the mother and calf .

#Text=I dropped my pole to which the lasso was attached , and allowed the little one to walk quickly away with it ; but , as I anticipated , the trailing shaft soon caught between the stumps of some trees , and made the calf a more secure prisoner than ever .
#Text=It was a curious repetition of the story of the two whales .
#Text=The mother walked round and round , and appeared to be in the greatest distress .
#Text=She never left her little one 's side , but continued to bellow loudly , and lick the calf to coax it away .
#Text=Quietly sliding down my tree , I made my way to where Yamba was still holding the attention of the bull -- a fiery brute who was pawing the ground with rage at the foot of her tree .
#Text=I had fitted an arrow to my bow , and was preparing to shoot , when , unfortunately , the bull detected the noise of my approach , and rushed straight at me .
#Text=I confess it was rather a trying moment , but I never lost my head , feeling confident of my skill with the bow -- which I had practised off and on ever since I had left school at Montreux .
#Text=I actually waited until the charging monster was within a few paces , and then I let fly .
#Text=So close was he that not much credit is due to me for accurate aim .
#Text=The arrow fairly transfixed his right eye , causing him to pull up on his haunches , and roar with pain .
#Text=Yamba , full of anxiety , hurried down her tree ; but she had scarcely reached the ground when the baffled bull wheeled and charged her , with more fury than ever .
#Text=She simply glided behind a tree , and then I showed myself and induced the bull to charge me once more .
#Text=Again I waited until he was almost upon me , and then I sent another arrow into his other eye , blinding him completely .
#Text=On this , the poor brute brought up sharp , and commenced to back in an uncertain way , bellowing with pain .
#Text=I forgot all my fever in the excitement , and rushing upon the beast with my tomahawk , I dealt him a blow on the side of the head that made him stagger .
#Text=I brought him to the earth with two or three more blows , and a few minutes later had administered the coup-de-grace .

#Text=No sooner was the big bull dead than I determined to test the efficacy of a very popular native remedy for fever -- for shivering fits still continued to come upon me at most awkward times , usually late in the day .
#Text=No matter how much grass poor Yamba brought me as covering , I never could get warm , and so now I thought I would try some animal heat .
